Actually you're wrong, EXAMPLE:
I would rather have coffe then have some fries. = I want fries After coffe

I would rather have fries than coffee= I would rather take fries before I even dare take some coffe 

So unless he was referring to something after something else "than" is correct

actually, i think he is right.

Than is a conjunction used in comparisons. Example: "Tom is smarter than Bill"

Then has numerous meanings:
1- At that point in time. Example: "I wasn’t ready then"
2- Next, afterward. Example: "Do your homework and then go to bed"
3- In addition, also, on top of that. Example: "He told me he was leaving, and then that I owed him money"
4- In that case, therefore. Example: "If you want to go, then you’ll have to finish your homework"

Let's take a look at our particular case: "What about Gragus **than**, he drinks beer all the time???"
We are in the 4th case of possible uses for the word "then", therefore that's the word he should have used.

That said, while correcting is good, i think you shouldn't use a tone that wants to belittle the one who did a mistake, especially if he is writing in a language he is not familiar with. I am pretty bad with english myself, and i will appreciate it if you tell me my mistakes, but you don't need to look down on me. I wouldn't do it if you were to try writing something in italian and do several mistakes.
So, Ironhold, while i understand you (i too dislike to see horrible grammar on my native language) you should be comprensive (keep correcting us, though, that's a good thing)
Literature Police watch out guys.

i like when people express themselves in a grammatically and syntactically correct way. Is that wrong of me?
Of course, everyone can do mistakes, that doesn't mean you are stupid, especially if you are writing in a language different from his native one. I myself do a lot of mistakes when i express myself in english, and sometimes even when i speak italian (i'm italian, btw). If i do, i take note of that for the future.
Since Arcade Andrew did a mistake, i made him notice. Did i look down on him because of that? not at all. Maybe later today he will correct some mistake of mine, and i'll thank him for that.

I haven't taken the mantle of educating/correcting people's vocabulary uppon this planet. But correcting than/then they're/their is like, one of the easiest if not the most basic things you can do, since it's expected from you, a non-native speaker, to not do such mistakes, whereas the native speakers keep hurting your eyes with their bad grammar.

Not only that, but their blatant refusal to comprehend their problem, as well as their innability to accept it, infuriates me greatly. Even the guy who corrected me, a native speaker, was wrong at his own language's grammar. Even if the use of "than" was correct, it still wouldn't stand in the structure of OP's sentence, hence STILL being wrong.

Lastly, I tried an accepting, friendly tone, the first 100 times. After that, you no longer walk on the valey of understanding, but you're swimming up the river of moronic stupidity. And that tends to make people bitter, especialy a cynical prick like myself. So that might explain to you why I no longer care about other people's feelings  when correcting them.

PS. Have my updoot for bothering to put into words what I would never do, because I consider knowing this kind of stuff for granted.

The initial complaint was about Riot's blatant and hypocritical double standards regarding depictions of drugs in media, not about whether someone is actually chugging a molotov.

Drop the cynical superiority complex.  Regardless of the composition of the chemicals that make up the molotov, it's common to use a glass alcohol container (beer bottles, etc) as a delivery system.

Slayer Jinx's Zap clearly uses an alcohol bottle as the delivery system of the molotov.  It's not like Riot designed a custom projectile or explosive that avoided the alcohol reference; they embraced the stereotype of using a beer bottle as the projectile, which is hypocritical to Riot's censoring of Graves's cigar as a removal of a drug reference (and the subsequent absence of censorship regarding the alcohol usage of Gragas and Yasuo, or the non-removal of the cigar on Esquire Gragas).

Don't distract from the issue with whether you can drink a molotov.  The issue is Riot is being hypocritical and arbitrary with their drug censorship.
